| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     | [SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line1575](/wiki/SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line1575 "SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/monst.c") |

A **werespider**, @ / s, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"). The werespider is an [omnivorous](/wiki/Omnivorous "Omnivorous") [human](/wiki/Human_\(monster_attribute\) "Human (monster attribute)") [werecreature](/wiki/Werecreature "Werecreature") that can shift between [human](/wiki/Human_or_elf "Human or elf") and [arachnid](/wiki/Arachnid_or_centipede "Arachnid or centipede") form - in both forms, they possess enhanced [regeneration](/wiki/Regeneration "Regeneration"). In human form, werespiders will seek out and pick up weapons and food.

A werespider in human form has a weapon attack—in [spider](/wiki/Spider "Spider") form, they have a strong bite that can cause [lycanthropy](/wiki/Lycanthropy "Lycanthropy") in the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero"), along with the ability to summon other spiders on nearby squares when in melee range. Werespiders possess [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") and [drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance"), and are weak to [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver").

A werespider [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") is [poisonous](/wiki/Poisonous "Poisonous") to [eat](/wiki/Eat "Eat"), and a hero eating a werespider corpse or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") will be given lycanthropy—a werespider that is [digested](/wiki/Digest "Digest") while in animal form can grant poison resistance.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 Origin](#Origin)
- [4 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)
- [5 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly-generated werespiders are always created hostile and in human form. They are not a valid form for normal [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph").

A werespider summoning help has a 4⁄5 chance of generating a hostile [cave spider](/wiki/Cave_spider "Cave spider") and a 1⁄5 chance of generating a hostile [recluse spider](/wiki/Recluse_spider "Recluse spider") on each applicable square[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)—heroes that get lycanthropy from a werespider can summon these monsters as pets using the [#monster](/wiki/Monster_\(command\) "Monster (command)") [extended command](/wiki/Extended_command "Extended command"), which costs 10 [power](/wiki/Power "Power"). In Hack'EM, this behavior is bugged to summon snakes and pit vipers as weresnakes do in SLASH'EM.

Werespiders may appear among the [@](/wiki/Human_or_elf "Human or elf") generated within the [Lawful Quest](/wiki/Lawful_Quest "Lawful Quest")'s Chamber of Junk, including ones that are generated as peaceful.

A werespider that leaves a [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") upon death will always leave a corpse of its human form: their animal form is considered to be [corpseless](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless").

## Strategy

Werecreatures in SLASH'EM and SlashTHEM are already made more dangerous than in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")* due to changes in [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") mechanics, which allows them to revert to human form if killed while in animal form—if the hero cannot dispatch the werecreature fast enough, they may have to be "killed" several times before going down for good.

As always, silver items are good options for dealing with werespiders and other lycanthropes, and there is a better selection of silver weapons and items available compared to *NetHack*. The [ring of protection from shape changers](/wiki/Ring_of_protection_from_shape_changers "Ring of protection from shape changers") is considerably stronger against lycanthropes, since they only need to be killed once while locked into human form, and cannot give the hero lycanthropy or summon help. [Ranged weapons](/wiki/Ranged_weapon "Ranged weapon") with [multishot](/wiki/Multishot "Multishot") bonuses can bring them down before they get close enough, and engraving [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth") can scare off both a werespider in animal form and any help they summon in order to either create space for an escape or more efficiently kill them.

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

*"Hack'EM specifics"*

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Therianthropy](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Therianthropy "wikipedia:Therianthropy")***

The concept of humans shapeshifting into animals has been a common concept in folklore among various human eras and cultures, while ["therianthropy"](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Therianthropy "wikipedia:Therianthropy") and related terms as a means of describing specific forms of human-animal shapeshifting have been in use since the early 20th century.

## Encyclopedia entry

- *See the [encyclopedia entry for werecreature](/wiki/Werecreature#Encyclopedia_entry "Werecreature").*

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [were.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 154](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/were.c#line154 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/were.c")

[![This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.](/images/3/38/Se7e7-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.")

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")

Werespider

From NetHackWiki

Difficulty 10
Attacks

Weapon 3d4

Base level 9
Base experience 191
Speed 12
Base AC 10
Base MR 20
Alignment -7 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 0 (Not randomly generated)
Genocidable No
Weight 1450
Nutritional value 400
Size Medium
Resistances poison
Resistances conveyed conveys lycanthropy

A human werespider:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • regenerates HP quickly.
  • is poisonous to eat.
  • is omnivorous.
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • can change between human and animal forms.
  • is a human.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
Reference SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line3678

Resistances poison
Resistances conveyed poison, conveys lycanthropy

An animal werespider:

  • has no hands.
  • is an animal.
  • can lay eggs.
  • regenerates HP quickly.
  • is poisonous to eat.
  • is carnivorous.
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • can change between human and animal forms.
  • is normally generated hostile.
Reference SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line1575

A werespider, @ / s, is a type of monster that appears in SLASH'EM, SlashTHEM and Hack'EM. The werespider is an omnivorous human werecreature that can shift between human and arachnid form - in both forms, they possess enhanced regeneration. In human form, werespiders will seek out and pick up weapons and food.

A werespider in human form has a weapon attack—in spider form, they have a strong bite that can cause lycanthropy in the hero, along with the ability to summon other spiders on nearby squares when in melee range. Werespiders possess poison resistance and drain resistance, and are weak to silver.

A werespider corpse is poisonous to eat, and a hero eating a werespider corpse or tin will be given lycanthropy—a werespider that is digested while in animal form can grant poison resistance.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 Origin
  • 4 Encyclopedia entry
  • 5 References

Generation

Randomly-generated werespiders are always created hostile and in human form. They are not a valid form for normal polymorph.

A werespider summoning help has a 4⁄5 chance of generating a hostile cave spider and a 1⁄5 chance of generating a hostile recluse spider on each applicable square[1]—heroes that get lycanthropy from a werespider can summon these monsters as pets using the #monster extended command, which costs 10 power. In Hack'EM, this behavior is bugged to summon snakes and pit vipers as weresnakes do in SLASH'EM.

Werespiders may appear among the @ generated within the Lawful Quest's Chamber of Junk, including ones that are generated as peaceful.

A werespider that leaves a corpse upon death will always leave a corpse of its human form: their animal form is considered to be corpseless.

Strategy

Werecreatures in SLASH'EM and SlashTHEM are already made more dangerous than in NetHack due to changes in polymorph mechanics, which allows them to revert to human form if killed while in animal form—if the hero cannot dispatch the werecreature fast enough, they may have to be "killed" several times before going down for good.

As always, silver items are good options for dealing with werespiders and other lycanthropes, and there is a better selection of silver weapons and items available compared to NetHack. The ring of protection from shape changers is considerably stronger against lycanthropes, since they only need to be killed once while locked into human form, and cannot give the hero lycanthropy or summon help. Ranged weapons with multishot bonuses can bring them down before they get close enough, and engraving Elbereth can scare off both a werespider in animal form and any help they summon in order to either create space for an escape or more efficiently kill them.

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

"Hack'EM specifics"

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Therianthropy

The concept of humans shapeshifting into animals has been a common concept in folklore among various human eras and cultures, while "therianthropy" and related terms as a means of describing specific forms of human-animal shapeshifting have been in use since the early 20th century.

Encyclopedia entry

See the encyclopedia entry for werecreature.

References

  1. ↑ were.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 154

A '''werespider''', {{monsym|werespider}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in [[SLASH'EM]], [[SlashTHEM]] and [[Hack'EM]]. The werespider is an [[omnivorous]] [[Human (monster attribute)|human]] [[werecreature]] that can shift between [[Human or elf|human]] and [[Arachnid or centipede|arachnid]] form - in both forms, they possess enhanced [[regeneration]]. In human form, werespiders will seek out and pick up weapons and food.

A werespider in human form has a weapon attack—in [[spider]] form, they have a strong bite that can cause [[lycanthropy]] in the [[hero]], along with the ability to summon other spiders on nearby squares when in melee range. Werespiders possess [[poison resistance]] and [[drain resistance]], and are weak to [[silver]].

A werespider [[corpse]] is [[poisonous]] to [[eat]], and a hero eating a werespider corpse or [[tin]] will be given lycanthropy—a werespider that is [[digest]]ed while in animal form can grant poison resistance.

==Generation==
Randomly-generated werespiders are always created hostile and in human form. They are not a valid form for normal [[polymorph]].

A werespider summoning help has a {{frac|4|5}} chance of generating a hostile [[cave spider]] and a {{frac|5}} chance of generating a hostile [[recluse spider]] on each applicable square{{refsrc|were.c|154|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}—heroes that get lycanthropy from a werespider can summon these monsters as pets using the [[Monster (command)|#monster]] [[extended command]], which costs 10 [[power]]. In Hack'EM, this behavior is bugged to summon snakes and pit vipers as weresnakes do in SLASH'EM.<!--awaiting fix before adjusting info-->

Werespiders may appear among the {{mcsl|@}} generated within the [[Lawful Quest]]'s Chamber of Junk, including ones that are generated as peaceful.

A werespider that leaves a [[corpse]] upon death will always leave a corpse of its human form: their animal form is considered to be [[corpseless]].

==Strategy==
Werecreatures in SLASH'EM and SlashTHEM are already made more dangerous than in ''[[NetHack]]'' due to changes in [[polymorph]] mechanics, which allows them to revert to human form if killed while in animal form—if the hero cannot dispatch the werecreature fast enough, they may have to be "killed" several times before going down for good.

As always, silver items are good options for dealing with werespiders and other lycanthropes, and there is a better selection of silver weapons and items available compared to ''NetHack''. The [[ring of protection from shape changers]] is considerably stronger against lycanthropes, since they only need to be killed once while locked into human form, and cannot give the hero lycanthropy or summon help. [[Ranged weapon]]s with [[multishot]] bonuses can bring them down before they get close enough, and engraving [[Elbereth]] can scare off both a werespider in animal form and any help they summon in order to either create space for an escape or more efficiently kill them.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Therianthropy}}
The concept of humans shapeshifting into animals has been a common concept in folklore among various human eras and cultures, while [[wikipedia:Therianthropy|"therianthropy"]] and related terms as a means of describing specific forms of human-animal shapeshifting have been in use since the early 20th century.
